Authors:
Miguel Angel Cruz-Espindola, Salvador Arias, Teresa
Terrazas
Title:
Molecular phylogeny and taxonomy of the genus Disocactus
(Cactaceae), based on the DNA sequences of six chloroplast markers.
Keywords:
Aporocactus, Bayesian Inference, Epiphyllinae, Epiphyllum,
epiphytic cacti, Hylocereinae, Maximum Parsimony, Pseudorhipsalis.
Abstract:
The genus Disocactus is native to Mexico and Central
America and includes 11 species on four subgenera: Ackermannia,
Aporocactus, Disocactus, and Nopalxochia. Phylogenetic reconstruction
was carried out with data from DNA sequences using the Maximum Parsimony
and Bayesian Inference criteria to explore the monophyly of the genus,
the subgenera and its position within Hylocereeae. Six chloroplast
markers (matK, psbA-trnH, rpl16, trnL-F, trnQ-rps16, ycf1) were
sequenced in 10 species of Disocactus, 17 representatives from the
remaining genera of Hylocereeae and five members of outgroups
(Acanthocereus, Lemaireocereus, and Pereskia). Our phylogenic analysis
supports neither the monophyly of Disocactus, as it is currently
defined, nor that of the subgenera. The clade Disocactus s.str. was
recovered for 13 species, including Epiphyllum anguliger, E. crenatum
and E. lepidocarpum. Three subclades were observed within this clade,
and three well-supported sister species relationships were recovered: D.
eichlamii and D. quezaltecus, D. biformis and D. nelsonii, D.
ackermannii and D. phyllanthoides. Disocactus speciosus subsp.
aurantiacus was not recovered in the clade of D. speciosus. Epiphyllum
and Pseudorhipsalis are identified as sister clades of Disocactus. Based
on results a new circumscription for Disocactus is proposed.
